goals: To help students become independent readers of nineteenth-century poetry from different European cultures and traditions.
To provide the opportunity for postgraduate students to present their work to fellow students and faculty.

syllabus:
**Course Description**

This course is designed to offer postgraduate students an introduction to the poetry and poetic culture of Europe during the nineteenth century. Although there is a bias on the course toward poetry written originally in English, we will be considering a great deal of poetry originally written in German, Italian and French through English translations from the nineteenth century and afterwards. The course is arranged in thematic units but in such a way that crucial developments in technique and subject matter can be appreciated from a chronological perspective. The course is not based on any single theoretical or methodological principle: biographical, historicist, materialist, philosophical, psychoanalytical, and (ultra-)close readings will undoubtedly all play a role in making sense of the poetry to hand.

**Schedule**

Week 1 Politics: Blake and Hölderlin

Week 2 Idylls and alienation: Leopardi and John Clare

Week 3 Skeptics and cosmopolitans #1: Byron and Percy Bysshe Shelley

Week 4 Skeptics and cosmopolitans #2: Heine and Pushkin

Week 5 Lateness: Goethe and Wordsworth

Week 6 Modern lives: Elizabeth Barrett Browning and Robert Browning

Week 7 HOLIDAY

Week 8 Skeptics and cosmopolitans #3: Arthur Hugh Clough and Matthew Arnold

Week 9 Dreams and other fragments #1: Tennyson,

Week 10 Dreams and other fragments #2: Dante Gabriel Rossetti and Christina Rossetti

Week 11 In the realm of the senses: Baudelaire, Swinburne, Arthur Symons, Ernest Dowson

Week 12 Aestheticisms: William Morris, Augusta Webster, Louisa Bevington, “Michael Field,” Amy Levy, Mary Robinson

Week 13 _Voyants_ #1: Emily Brontë, Gerard Manley Hopkins

Week 14 _Voyants_ #2: Rimbaud

Week 15 _Jouissance_: Mallarmé

Week 16 Consolidation class

Weeks 17 and 18 Self-supported study toward FINAL essay

Essay (70%) (c. 3000 words)

Students will write an essay on the work of two to three poets studied in the course. Students are encouraged to write about poets who were not read together in the same week of the course. Students may devise their own essay title and are not required to cleave to any particular theoretical or methodological principle in their writing. The completed essay should be emailed to [aaron.c.deveson@gmail.com](mailto:aaron.c.deveson@gmail.com). In the case of late submissions, 5% will be deducted for every day by which the assignment is late. 

Individual presentation (30%).

The presenting student will use but not simply read from Powerpoint slides. The presentation will typically introduce the life and work of a particular writer. It must refer in a general way to at least four poems and provide a detailed analysis of one of those poems. It must contain at least three images. It should last between 18 and 20 minutes.

Course dossier provided. This will include poems by authors listed above but also paratextual materials
